title: 110_hr2214
content: The Act may be cited as the "Adults Achieving the American Dream Act of 2007". Congress finds that 93 million adults in the United States have limited literacy skills, 16 percent of adults lack a high school diploma, 23 million individuals struggle with English proficiency, 8 million lawful permanent residents are eligible for citizenship, and there are waiting lists for Adult ESL programs. Only three percent of the 93 million adults in the United States who could benefit from adult education services actually participate in such programs due to extreme demand. There is a growing and urgent need for additional adult education, English literacy, and civics education programs. Amendments are proposed to the Adult Education and Family Literacy Act to address the growing need for adult education, English literacy, and civics education programs. Amendments to the Adult Education and Family Literacy Act introduce an Integrated English Literacy and Civics Education Program, aimed at helping individuals with limited English proficiency gain English skills through instruction on citizenship, naturalization, civic participation, and U.S. history and government. The Adult Education and Family Literacy Act is amended to allocate increasing funds for fiscal years 2008 to 2013. Section 211(a) is also amended to increase the reservation of funds for the program. Section 242(c)(1) is also amended to include effective practices in integrated English literacy and civics education programs. SEC. 244 addresses the Integrated English Literacy and Civics Education Programs. The Secretary will award grants to States for integrated English literacy and civics education programs from reserved funds. Allocations are based on a State's need, calculated using data on immigrants admitted for lawful permanent residence. The Secretary will allocate funds to States based on growth in immigrants admitted for lawful permanent residence, with a minimum allocation of $60,000 per State. SEC. 4 amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to authorize $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2008 and additional funds for the following 5 years for Even Start family literacy programs. SEC. 5 focuses on research in adult education. The Secretary of Education will establish a national research and development center for adult education and literacy as part of the Education Sciences Reform Act of 2002. The Commissioner will expand the research topic of the national center for adult education and literacy in accordance with the Education Sciences Reform Act of 2002. The Secretary of Homeland Security will transfer funds to the Secretary of Education for English literacy and civics education programs for immigrants. Additionally, a new tax credit is introduced for employers who provide adult English literacy and basic education programs. A new tax credit is introduced for employers who provide qualified education program expenses for employees with limited English proficiency or lacking basic education. The credit is 20% of expenses, capped at $1,000 per full-time employee. The term 'qualified education' refers to adult education and literacy activities provided by eligible providers receiving Federal funds or in approved curriculum. Other defined terms include 'individuals of limited English proficiency', 'eligible provider', 'adult education and literacy activities', and 'eligible agency'. Special rules for full-time employment include working at least 30 hours per week for 25 or more weeks in a year. All related entities are treated as one for tax purposes. No double benefits are allowed, and taxpayers can choose to opt out of the credit. The Secretary may prescribe regulations for exceptions to this section. The adult English literacy and basic education programs credit is added to the general business credit. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. Employer-provided adult English literacy and basic education programs credit effective for taxable years after December 31, 2007.
